The awkward fact that the homeric kings had no deputies is met by the daring suggestion that the heralds acted as such,  and that their functions »could well give rise to the corresponding powers of the Spartan Ephors « ( p.  400 ),  e.  g.  in summoning the Gerousia to hold a trial and in summoning the Apella.  The part played by Chilon in the development of the Ephors' powers receives very little notice,  and no explanation is given for printing his name as Cheilon. 
The study of the Rhetra ( examined more fully in Appendix VI,  pp.  474—489 ) leads to the following conclusions : that the »Lycurgan« constitution had long existed before the time of Tyrtaeus ; that the Rhetra consists of two parts,  representing two chronological stages in its ment,  the first being the oracle supposedly given at Delphi to Lycurgus,  instructing a single legislator to lay the proposals before the Assembly and then resign his function ( oßtcog eiacpéQsiv re xal àcpùrtaa'd'aî ) ; the second part an enactment of purely Spartan origin,  of which the Gerousia and kings were the authors,  limiting the Assembly's right of ratification to the judicial sphere,  but not giving it the wider powers indicated by Tyrtaeus's version,  which extended them to deliberations in general.  This second part,  it is claimed,  may well date from the time of the first Messenian War,  in accordance with the tradition which ascribed it to Theopompus and Polydorus. 
Herodotus,  it is argued,  is not following a separate tradition in his account of Lycurgus ( i.  65 ) but is trying to give a paraphrase of the terms used in the first part of the Rhetra ; but we must accept the fact that he is mistaken in almost every detail.  ( But can he really have interpreted àTzeXXdCetv as referring to the Syssitia,  and àQxayéxat as the Ephors?  )
Turning to the details of »Part I«,  we may readily agree that the fixing of the numbers of the Gerousia implies that it was already in existence as a body,  but there is no evidence whatsoever for the suggestion that viously it had consisted ( in theory at least ) of twenty - seven members,  nine from each tribe ; and the further assumption that the change in numbers »may be reasonably connected« with the addition of a second king comes as rather a shock.  It seems almost inconceivable that so momentous and unparalleled a step as the creation or recognition of a double monarchy could have been brought about on the strength of the two words ovv àQXdyéxatÇy and any conclusions based on this view must be firmly rejected. 
As to the interpretation of the instructions for the meeting - place of the Apella ( cf.  App.  VI.  p.  48 5 f.  ) more will be said later.
